What an amazing place to stay! For starters parking was excellent. We had a front row spot right by our door everyday. As you walk up the stairs and into the hallway you’re greeted with beautiful hardwood floors and lovely light fixtures that take you back in time. At this point you can already tell this building was meticulously restored to its original state.
The room itself has a great amount of natural light. Lay down in the bed and look up to take in the most gorgeous skylight you’ve ever seen. That was hands down my favorite feature. And don’t you worry about street traffic waking you up. The room has a sound machine that drowns if all out. A very nice touch, and something you can remove from your packing list.
The living space is open with very large windows that have a touch of stained glass at the top. Peek out the windows to take in views of the pristine Dallas County Library and a pretty little fountain at city hall. At this point you’ll be torn between hanging out inside the loft or hitting the streets of Selma to meet some of the nicest people around!
Everything in the loft is clean, freshly painted, and uniquely decorated. You can’t get this level of comfort and style at a hotel! Come visit!

Great location for direct access to Selma. Quiet, well-kept neighborhood of apartment duplexes.
Inside, the air felt nice, cool, and fresh with solid AC.
Enjoyed maps and rustic feel, and appreciated the rustic headboard lamps in the master suite for evening reading.
The 2 bed/2 BR each, which had a classic and simple design.
Mattress and bed/BR linen choice was most disappointing.
While it beat the alternative of sleeping in a tent for the entirety of the [wet] weekend, the full-sized, stiff boxspring wasn't comfortable--especially if sharing a bed. Felt like sleeping on very* cheap linen and pillows, but was clean.
Same with the white towels and rags in the BRs, but unfortunately very cheap rags/towels do not handle wear well from previous use, though presumed clean, of course. Quality in these regards goes a long way.
Freezer handle wasn't secure and was like halfway popped off, but was clean and cold nonetheless.
For the location and price, it really was a solid BnB!

review_text: If you want to submerge yourself in the history and culture of the South, you’re at the epicenter when staying at the Woolworth Lofts in Selma. AC, who owns and operates this small collection of units renovated from the old Woolworth Building, has added her loving touch – creating a cozy hideaway (mine was Suite B) tucked off the main street that is both a traveler's refuge and itself a space that speaks to the historical importance of Selma and contemporary elements of its location along the Alabama River. In fact, you'll enjoy all the creature comforts of an upscale Airbnb – but with plenty of room and amenities of a spacious apartment you'll wish you owned! There's no better guide than AC to point you in the direction of significant landmarks, and to introduce you to local characters that literally bridge the past of the Edmund Pettis Bridge to the present, as Selma continues struggling to shape its identity in the modern world. Don't miss out on the next door "5 and Dime" (of course) art gallery – an expansive space that rotates a variety of award-winning artists on a monthly basis. Art from the heart, I came to think of it: local artists, including several important figures, who represent the fiber of the region, creating art that lets through creases of light through their mostly three-dimensional work. Character, cleanliness and culture -- my 3 Cs (+ AC!) when traveling, and the cornerstones of an amazing experience you'll enjoy when you make the Woolworth Loft your home in Selma for a brief visit (mine was three very full days) or a long-term stay. Highly recommended.

The host provides sound machines in each bedroom that help, but do not eliminate the street noise. Small price to pay for a wonderful location, but worth being prepared for.
